brief_summary.textblock:
Tobacco use is the number one killer of Americans today. Most current smokers have tried and
      failed to quit at least once. Smokers are addicted to the nicotine in tobacco products, and
      withdrawal from smoking can lead to physical symptoms such as irritability, anxiety,
      nervousness, depression and insomnia.

      This study will examine the effects of tobacco cessation counseling and chiropractic
      treatments on smokers who desire to quit.

clinical_study.brief_title: Chiropractic Treatment With Counseling Versus Counseling Alone for Promoting Smoking Cessation

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Adults 18 yrs and above

          -  Smokers with desire to quit smoking

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Received chiropractic treatment or other manipulative therapies within the last month

          -  Have received any therapy for smoking cessation during the last month

          -  Visceral, systemic or joint inflammatory disease

          -  A history of low back surgery

          -  Osteoporosis

          -  Prolonged systemic corticosteroid medication

          -  Pregnancy

          -  Recent spinal fracture

intervention.description: Full spine high velocity, low amplitude manipulation of the spine

clinical_study.official_title: Chiropractic Treatment With Counseling Versus Counseling Alone for Promoting Smoking Cessation: A Randomized Clinical Trial

overall_official.affiliation: Southern California University of Health Sciences

primary_outcome.time_frame: Smoking diary will be complete for 3 months

primary_outcome.description: An urinary test for nicotine metabolites

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Southern California University of Health Sciences

clinical_study.source: Southern California University of Health Sciences

lead_sponsor.agency: Southern California University of Health Sciences

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Treatment
